_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Containers must meet U.S. DOT Specifications (UN Performance Oriented Standards)
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: See Chlorine Institute Pamphlets for container construction details.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Emergency Kit A with SO2 gaskets for cylinders, Kit B with SO2 gaskets for tons or Salvage Cylinder cylinders will be used to mitigate and stop leaks.
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Facility is manned 24/7.  Security guards perform patrols at periodic intervals during non-operational hours.
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Sulfur Dioxide filling and processing ceased at this location.  Containers are filled and arrive from our Henderson, KY facility.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Fork-lift used to transport containers back and forth from trailers to warehouse.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
SDS for each of the three covered chemicals are kept on file at this facility.  A copy of the SDS for Sulfur Dioxide is also located under Process Safety Information in the Orlando RMP Program.  Equipment specifications are kept on file at this facility for equipment that is used to store or transport these chemicals.  Unloading/loading of these covered chemicals is covered by a procedure in our Operations Procedure Manual.  Specifications for containers of Sulfur Dioxide are regulated by the U.S. Department of Transportation.  Container specfication may be found under the Process Safety Information in the Orlando RMP Program. Training on handling, loading/unloading and emergency response was conducted in 2017.



ORLANDO SULFUR DIOXIDE PROCESS



Sulfur Dioxide is received pre-packaged at this facility via van trailers from our Henderson, KY facility.  Both cylinders and ton container are unloaded fron trailer and then moved to storage for subsequent distribution to our customers.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: (1) Chlorine system is visually inspected daily prior to startup. (2) Prior to being filled, every chlorine container is inspected & valves plus one fuse plug is reconditioned in each ton container.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
SDS for each of the three covered chemicals are kept on file at this facility.  A copy of the SDS for Chlorine is also located in under Process Safety Information in the Orlando RMP Program.  Equipment specifications are kept on file at this facility for equipment that is used to store or transport these chemicals.  Unloading/loading of these covered chemicals is covered by a procedure in our Operations Procedure Manual.  Material of construction on containers for chlorine is located in the Chlorine Institute pamphlet. Training on handling, loading/unloading and emergency response kits was conducted in 2017.



ORLANDO CHLORINE PROCESS



Chlorine at this facility is received via railcars that contain approximately 180,000 pounds of chlorine.  Chlorine railcars are connected to our piping and delivery system on a daily basis (typically Monday - Friday or 5 days each week).  Chlorine is routed via our piping system to the following locations:



1. Chlorine Container Fill Room (Cylinders and Ton Containers are filled in this area.)

2. Continuous Bleach Production Unit (Powell Unit)



Chlorine is also evacuated from our process piping on a daily basis for shutdown.  Evacuated chlorine is directed to a caustic scrubber system known as the "process tank".  Chlorine is also evacuated from the vacuum side of our chlorine container filling operations continuously during operation. Empty containers are filled as as returned containers are evacuated for visual inspection and/or periodic retesting.  The evacuated chlorine is directed to the "process tank" described above.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Containers must meet U.S. Department of Transportation Specificaitons
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Transfer hoses are selected based on product compability and operating pressures/temperatures.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Absorbents to dike, contain and absorb spills.
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Aqua Ammonia is being moved from Program 3 to Program 2 since it is not covered by PSM under 29 CFR 1910.119 and neither does it fall under the NAICS codes listed in 68.10(d)(1).
_prev_prog_2.Description:
SDS for each of the three covered chemicals are kept on file at this facility.  A copy of the SDS for Aqua Ammonia is also located in under Process Safety Information in the Orlando RMP Program.  Equipment specifications are kept on file at this facility for equipment that is used to store or transport these chemicals.  Unloading/loading of these covered chemicals is covered by a procedure in our Operations Procedure Manual.  Specifications on containers for Aqua Ammonia are regulated by the U.S. Department of Transportation.  Container specifications may be found under the Process Safety Information in the Orlando RMP Program. Training on handling, loading/unloading and emergency response was conducted in 2017.



ORLANDO AQUA AMMONIA PROCESS



Aqua Ammonia at this facility is received via tank trailers that contain approximately 45,000 pounds of aqua ammonia.  We direct drum from the tanker trailer and fill 15 gallon and 55 gallon poly drums as well as 330 gallon poly Intermediate Bulk Containers (IBC's)  These containers are then moved to storage for subsequent distribution to our customers.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
General Executive Summary for Chemical, Manufacturing and Oil Refining Facilities





1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

We at Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This is evidenced through our Core Values found in the Brenntag Cornerstone.  The six (6)core values of Brenntag Connecting Chemistry  are: SAFETY FIRST, LEADERSHIP & ACCOUNTABILITY, EMPLOYEE INVOLVEMENT AND OWNERSHIP, COMMITMENT TO EXCELLENCE, Integrity Responsibility, and Value Creation for Partners CONTINUOUS.  As stated by Mr. William A. Filder, President & CEO of Brenntag North America and Latin America; "Nothing we do can ever become more important than our safety performance." and "There is not business goal worth asking people to sacrifice what they value most in life."  This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, we are completely coordinated with ORLANDO FIRE DEPARTMENT which provides highly trained emergency response personnel to control and mitigate the effects of a release.



2.    The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The Orlando facility's primary activities include the repackaging and distribution of chemical products.  We have three (3) regulated substances present at the Orlando facility.  These substances include Chlorine, Sulfur Dioxide (anhydrous and Aqua Ammonia.  Chlorine is received into Orlando in 180,000 pound railcars.  Chlorine is repackaged in different  containers and used to produce bleach (sodium hypochlorite)for distribution to our customers.  The Sulfur Dioxide containers are packaged at our Henderson, KY facility and

are stored, handled and distributed to our customers.  Aqua Ammonia is received from our supplier in tanker trailer quantities of approximately 45,000 lbs and repackaged directly into 15, 55, and 330 gallon poly drums and totes.  



The maximum inventory of Chlorine at our facility is 2,235,000 lbs. while Sulfur dioxide (anhydrous), and Aqua Ammonia are present at our facility in quantities of 55,000 lbs. and 173,835 respectively.



3.    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA STANDARD 30-1996).  The chlorine process at our facility is subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.



The following sections briefly describe the elements of our release prevention program that are in place at our stationary source.



Process Safety Information

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.



Process Hazard Analysis

Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is "WHAT IF".  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of five (5)years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

 

Operating Procedures



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary opera

tions, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.



Training

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently.  Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper functions.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Brenntag Mid-South, Inc.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startu

p prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.



 

Incident Investigation

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facilityA?s implementation to the RMP rule in particular information resulting from process hazard analyses.



Contractors

On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractors work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.



4.    Five-year Accident History

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. has had 1 accidental releases involving covered chemicals over the last 5 years.



5.    Emergency Response Plan

Brenntag Mid-South, Inc. carries a written emergency response

plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.



To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.



District 6 is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

 



6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program.  A team of compressed gas experts from across Brenntag North America as well as regional and local personnel continue to evaluate our safety systems at this location.
